posts.post_content: @Hydrogoose: Uh, no, this is way better than Llanowar Elves, for the following reasons: A) Llanowar Elves does not have haste, and therefore cannot use its tap ability turn 1, and B) This costs 0cmc, whereas LE costs 1cmc. What that means is that the best the Elves can do is get you generating 2 mana turn 2, whereas this can get you generating 2 mana turn 1. Also, because it costs 0 it means that if your opening hand has multiples you can drop them all at once, potentially getting as much as 5 mana turn 1.
posts.html:

What that means is that the best the Elves can do is get you generating 2 mana turn 2, whereas this can get you generating 2 mana turn 1. posts.post_content:
Of course Turn 1 wins abound with the Moxen/Black Lotus, but I figured I'd jot mine down.  
  
Step 1) Play [Mountain](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mountain), [Mox Sapphire](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mox Sapphire), [Black Lotus](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Black Lotus)  
Step 2) Tap [Mountain](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mountain), tap [Mox Sapphire](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mox Sapphire), tap/sac [Black Lotus](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Black Lotus) for {R}{R}{R}  
Step 3) Play [Kiln Fiend](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Kiln Fiend)  
Step 4) Play [Chaos Charm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Chaos Charm) (choosing haste), play [Assault Strobe](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Assault Strobe), play [Distortion Strike](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Distortion Strike)  
Step 5) Swing for 22 unblockable damage.  
Step 6) Gloat
posts.html:
Of course Turn 1 wins abound with the Moxen/Black Lotus, but I figured I'd jot mine down.

Step 1) Play Mountain, Mox Sapphire, Black Lotus
Step 2) Tap Mountain, tap Mox Sapphire, tap/sac Black Lotus for {R}{R}{R}
Step 3) Play Kiln Fiend
Step 4) Play Chaos Charm (choosing haste), play Assault Strobe, play Distortion Strike
Step 5) Swing for 22 unblockable damage.
Step 6) Gloat

posts.post_content: I am convinced the designers of the game 'Anti-Monopoly' play Magic: the Gathering. Go out and buy copy. I shit you not, one of the tokens you can choose to play as is a Mox Sapphire. My brother and I opened the box, glanced over the rules, determined the writers knew nothing at all about economics but maybe a lot about game design, and then we saw the piece of wood carved into a MOX SAPPHIRE....and promptly had a tug of war of it. We decided whoever controlled Mox Sapphire at the end of the tug of war should be declared the winner. This game is a lot more fun than actually playing Anti-Monopoly :)
posts.html:
